Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation: Forming the Empathic Engineer - A Path to Gender Equity in the Profession

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The current identity of many engineering education programs lacks empathy as a core element. This could be a barrier to entry for women and may also be in conflict with the human-centered values expressed by engineering's professional organizations. To increase the enrollment of women in certain sub-disciplines of engineering, a reformulation of engineering identity to consciously incorporate empathy may be required. This research effort is centered on characterizing the empathetic aspects of this identity within some of the sub-disciplines of engineering and identifying the degree to which a perceived lack of empathy forms a barrier for women pursuing engineering as a field of study. A future effort will formulate methods of transforming faculty and student attitudes to be more empathetic. It is believed that this will lead to the formation of an engineering identity that is more open to the concerns of women and more consistent with the values defined in the professional codes and creeds. The broader impacts are threefold. First, this work could point the way to increasing the representation of women in fields such as electrical, computer, and mechanical engineering. By quantifying the role that empathy plays in the identity of potential engineering students and formulating methods to increase focus on empathetic activities as part of the engineering education process, women may find a greater affinity for disciplines that have suffered from underrepresentation. Second is the potential change for engineering students as a whole. Activities such as working in teams, managing the efforts of others, and identifying with consumers of products are all enhanced through skills in empathy. The final impact is a shift in focus toward more empathetic endeavors bringing greater resonance between the training a student receives and the objectives outlined in the professional societies' identity statements. There is an opportunity with this research to empower young engineers to actually do what they are encouraged to do in every graduation speech: make the world better.

This research will be performed using two instruments administered over a two-year period. The first is a quantitative survey instrument that will measure: 1) empathy of the participant, 2) perceived empathy of engineering and non-engineering disciplines, 3) likelihood of choosing an engineering or non-engineering discipline for study, and 4) perceived empathy of the current faculty and students in the major of study. Survey results will be solicited from a pool of 4000 participants taken from STEM and non-STEM majors. Based on an analysis of the results of this survey, a qualitative focus group study will be performed using a semi-structured protocol. This qualitative component will further explore the empathetic factors related to choice of major among students. The study will be administered to groups of only men, only women, and mixed groups. Groups will be composed of 5-10 volunteers at three separate universities. The proposed research is significant because it seeks to assess, for the first time, empathy among students and faculty and to attempt to relate this to the participation of women in engineering programs. This study will contribute to a greater understanding of the role empathy plays in the diversity of engineering programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to understand the role empathy plays in the disparate representation of women in engineering. We used two methods of analysis. First, we surveyed 517 students enrolled in STEM and non-STEM majors. Women represented 46% of the responses and 34% were non-STEM majors. We assessed beliefs about engineering as a major and about engineering students and faculty. We also measured the empathy of each participant using a modified version of a standard test for quantifying empathy. This test produces a quotient for the tendency of a person to empathize (EQ) or systematize (SQ). We examined the ratio of these quotients and found the following: 1) female and non-STEM students had significantly higher EQ/SQ ratios than male and STEM students, respectively.  2) In engineering majors that had sufficient sample sizes (n > 5), the general pattern was that female students had higher EQ/SQ ratio than male students. 3) Controlling for differences in EQ/SQ ratios, male and female students had significant differences in their perceived level of empathy in mechanical engineering and elementary education. Specifically, female students reported significantly lower empathy perception about mechanical engineering than males, but significantly higher empathy perception than males about elementary education. 4) Students? EQ/SQ ratio was positively related to their likelihood of choosing a non-STEM major, but negatively related to their likelihood of choosing a STEM major. 

The second method of analysis was to conduct focus group interviews. The themes we observed in focus group participant responses validate the application of a person-environment fit framework for examining college major choice. Our findings suggest that women value the practical application of empathy in engineering and are drawn to the goal of helping others through their work. Women appreciate being able to incorporate empathy into their work and see it as an integral part of what drives engineering advancement. When they saw their values align with the work they could do in their major, they reported satisfaction and purpose behind their studies and future work. However, this purpose was often missing when they thought of engineering as purely rational, logical, math-oriented, and rigid. When women felt the major?s culture and values were incongruent with their own, they made the decision to leave their field or cited that discordance as an area of current frustration within their major. We also found that men could play a significant postive role in infuencing a woman's choice of engineering as a major. We noted that male figures such as fathers and teachers were cited by our participants as a significant factor in them choosing an engineering major. 

The culture of the department remains a salient factor in women?s choice of major. The women cited the gendered culture, both in numbers and in norms and behavior, as an obstacle for feeling like they fit in. While the female engineers indicated that the gender imbalance did not deter them from entering and remaining in engineering, it was a constant reminder that they were the ?other? and the outsider which can lead to feelings of tokenism and stereotyping. As noted by our women participants this might prevent other women from entering engineering fields, yet they were not dissuaded due to their strong, independent, confident personalities. It is important to note that even the perceived culture dissuades women from pursuing STEM fields. For one woman, she did not even consider a STEM field based on her perception that those fields were unfriendly to women, and men had an inherent advantage in those disciplines. 

The research conducted under this grant has the potential to impact the recruitment, retention, and motivation of women in engineering. It has been recognized that female role models for women in engineering are a factor in recruiting women into engineering disciplines. How do we find more women as role models when so few enter the profession? A potential easing of this problem exists in the observation that role models and mentors other than women (fathers and male math and science teachers) can have signficant impact. When initiating efforts at recruitment, programs may use this observation to recruit young women into engineering. 

           Retaining women in engineering is a problem in many engineering disciplines. We observed that the culture of departments can play a significant role in retention. Programs to educate both students and faculty on the struggles that women face in engineering is needed to avoid the negative experiences we observed in our focus groups. Establishing support groups for women in engineering majors may also be needed. 

The results of this research indicate that women specifically care about things that benefit people and society in general as expressed in their increase in empathizing over systematizing. Emphasizing the empathetic aspects of engineering throughout the education process will help to motivate all students and women in particular.
